lines.content: It seems there was an issue generating the markdown file for the user guide. I'll provide you with the full markdown content here so that you can copy it into your own markdown file.

Welcome to **Andy Bot**, your personal assistant to manage tasks, deadlines, and events effortlessly. Andy helps you keep track of all your tasks with an easy-to-use interface, and all your inputs are stored safely so you never lose track of important tasks.

Andy Bot is designed to help you stay on top of your task management. You can add, delete, and mark tasks as done, as well as search for specific tasks in your list. Andy supports three types of tasks: ToDo, Deadline, and Event tasks.
- **Deadline**: Task with a name and a deadline.
- **Event**: Task with a name, start time, and end time.
Andy stores all your tasks in a file called **andy.txt** located in the `data` directory. If the file doesn't exist, Andy will automatically create it for you when you first run the application.
- Latest JAR file of Andy Bot
1. Open your terminal or command prompt.
2. Change directory to the location where the JAR file is stored.
To exit the application, simply type `bye`.
Displays all tasks in the current list.
Adds a task with the specified name.
Now you have 1 task in the list.
Adds a task with a specified deadline.
Adds an event task with a start and end time.
Marks a task at the specified index as done.
Nice! I've marked this task as done:
Marks a task at the specified index as not done.
OK, I've marked this task as not done yet:
Deletes the task at the specified index.
Finds and displays all tasks that match the specified keyword.
Here are the matching tasks in your list:
Closes Andy Bot and saves your tasks.
This is a project template for a greenfield Java project. It's named after the Java mascot _Duke_. Given below are instructions on how to use it.
Prerequisites: JDK 17, update Intellij to the most recent version.
1. Open Intellij (if you are not in the welcome screen, click `File` > `Close Project` to close the existing project first)
1. Open the project into Intellij as follows:
1. Select the project directory, and click `OK`.
1. If there are any further prompts, accept the defaults.
1. Configure the project to use **JDK 17** (not other versions) as explained in [here](https://www.jetbrains.com/help/idea/sdk.html#set-up-jdk).
In the same dialog, set the **Project language level** field to the `SDK default` option.

3. After that, locate the `src/main/java/Duke.java` file, right-click it, and choose `Run Duke.main()` (if the code editor is showing compile errors, try restarting the IDE). If the setup is correct, you should see something like the below as the output:
* Main class for the Andy task manager application. It handles user input,
* manages tasks, and interacts with storage, UI, and other components.
* Constructor for Andy. Initializes UI, Storage, TaskList, and Parser.
* @param filePath the file path where the tasks are stored.
storage = new Storage(filePath);  // Initialize Storage with file path
tasks = new TaskList(storage.loadTasks());  // Load tasks from storage
* Starts the main loop of the Andy task manager.
* Continuously processes user input until the user enters "bye".
// Main loop to process user input
String command = parser.parseCommand(input);  // Get the command
tasks.addTask(new TodoTask(todoDescription));  // Add new todo task
tasks.addTask(new DeadlineTask(parts[0], parts[1]));  // Add deadline task
tasks.addTask(new EventTask(parts[0], timeParts[0], timeParts[1]));  // Add event task
List<Task> foundTasks = tasks.findTasks(keyword);  // Find tasks by keyword
int index = parser.parseTaskIndex(input);  // Parse the index to delete
Task deletedTask = tasks.getTask(index);  // Get the task to be deleted
int markIndex = parser.parseTaskIndex(input);  // Parse the index to mark as done
tasks.getTask(markIndex).setDone(true);  // Mark the task as done
int unmarkIndex = parser.parseTaskIndex(input);  // Parse the index to unmark
tasks.getTask(unmarkIndex).setDone(false);  // Unmark the task as not done
// Save updated task list after each command
ui.showErrorMessage(e.getMessage());  // Handle any exceptions with an error message
* Main method to start the Andy task manager application.
// Implementing the task type for DeadlineTask
public EventTask(String description, String from, String to) {
// New method to return event details as a string (from and to times)
return from + " /to " + to;  // Returns the event details as "from /to to"
* The Parser class is responsible for interpreting user input.
* It extracts commands, task descriptions, and task indexes from the input string.
* Parses the command from the user input.
* @param input The full user input string.
* @return The command, which is the first word of the input string.
return input.split(" ")[0];  // Get the first word as the command
* Parses the task description from the user input based on the command.
* Throws an AndyException if the description is empty.
* @param input The full user input string.
* @param command The command for which the task description is being parsed.
* @return The task description, trimmed of excess spaces.
* @throws AndyException if the task description is empty.
public String parseTaskDescription(String input, String command) throws AndyException {
throw new AndyException("Task description cannot be empty.");
* Parses the task index from the user input.
* Throws an AndyException if the index is invalid or cannot be parsed.
* @param input The full user input string containing the task index.
* @return The task index as an integer (0-based).
* @throws AndyException if the task index is invalid or cannot be parsed.
public int parseTaskIndex(String input) throws AndyException {
return Integer.parseInt(parts[1]) - 1;  // Task index is usually the second word
* The Storage class is responsible for reading and writing tasks from and to a file.
* It handles the loading of tasks from a file during startup and saves tasks back to the file.
* @param filePath The path to the file where tasks are stored.
* Loads tasks from the specified file. If the file does not exist, returns an empty task list.
* @return A list of tasks loaded from the file.
* Saves the given list of tasks to the file.
* @param tasks The list of tasks to be saved to the file.
* The abstract Task class represents a generic task in the task manager.
* It provides common functionality such as managing the task's description and completion status.
* Subclasses must implement the abstract getType() method to define the type of task.
* Initializes a task with a given description and marks it as not done.
* @param description The description of the task.
* Retrieves the description of the task.
* Checks if the task is marked as done.
* @return True if the task is done, false otherwise.
* Marks the task as done or not done.
* @param done True to mark the task as done, false to mark it as not done.
* Abstract method to retrieve the type of task.
* Subclasses must implement this method to define their specific task type.
* @return The type of task as a string.
* Returns a string representation of the task, including its completion status.
* @return A string in the format "[X] description" if done, or "[ ] description" if not done.
* The TaskList class manages a list of Task objects. It provides functionality
* to add, delete, and search for tasks, as well as retrieve tasks by their index.
* Default constructor for TaskList. Initializes an empty list of tasks.
* Constructor for TaskList that accepts a list of tasks.
* @param tasks A list of Task objects to initialize the TaskList with.
* Retrieves the current list of tasks.
* Adds a task to the list.
* @param task The Task object to be added to the list.
* Deletes a task from the list by its index.
* @param index The index of the task to be deleted.
* Retrieves a task by its index.
* @param index The index of the task to retrieve.
* @return The Task object at the specified index.
* Returns the number of tasks in the list.
* @return The size of the task list.
* Checks if the task list is empty.
* @return True if the task list is empty, false otherwise.
* Finds tasks that match a given keyword.
* @param keyword The keyword to search for in task descriptions.
* @return A list of tasks that contain the keyword.
* Returns a string representation of the task list, with each task numbered.
* @return A string containing the numbered list of tasks.
private static final String FILE_PATH = "./data/andy.txt";  // Updated to 'andy.txt'
// Method to load tasks from a file
return tasks;  // Return an empty list if the file doesn't exist
// Check if the line contains at least 3 parts (taskType, isDone, description)
continue;  // Skip to the next line without printing anything
// Check if we have enough parts for DeadlineTask
// Check if we have enough parts for EventTask
String eventDetails = parts[3];  // This holds the "from /to to" format
// Ensure the eventParts contains both "from" and "to"
tasks.add(task);  // Add the task to the list
// Method to save tasks to a file
directory.mkdirs();  // Create the directory if it doesn't exist
// Write each task to the file
writer.write(taskLine + System.lineSeparator());  // Write task to file
writer.close();  // Close the writer after saving
// Implementing the abstract getType() method from Task
return "[T] " + super.toString();  // Add [T] to the string representation of the task
* The UI class is responsible for handling all user interactions.
* It shows messages, receives input, and displays tasks.
* Constructor for UI. Initializes the Scanner to capture user input.
* Displays the welcome message when the program starts.
* Gets the user input from the console.
* @return The user's input as a string.
* Displays the goodbye message when the program ends.
System.out.println("Bye. Hope to see you again soon!");
* Displays the list of tasks that match the user's search keyword.
* @param tasks The list of tasks matching the search criteria.
System.out.println("Here are the matching tasks in your list:");
* Displays a message when a new task is added.
* @param description The description of the added task.
* Displays a message when a task is deleted.
* @param description The description of the deleted task.
* Displays a message when a task is marked as done.
* @param task The task that has been marked as done.
System.out.println("Nice! I've marked this task as done:");
* Displays a message when a task is unmarked (marked as not done).
* @param task The task that has been unmarked.
System.out.println("OK, I've marked this task as not done yet:");
* Displays the list of all tasks.
* @param tasks The TaskList containing all tasks.
* Displays an error message when an exception or error occurs.
* @param message The error message to be displayed.
